questions.text: A 30-year-old man comes with multiple circular, dry, scaly, itchy lesions on the scalp.  On further examination, it is seen that hair is involved but nails are spared. Scrapings from the lesion are inoculated and examined microscopically. Identify the dermatophyte based on the macroconidia seen in the image below.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of infection involving skin and hair, sparing the nails and the image showing large spindle-shaped macroconidia is a feature of Microsporum.

Dermatophytosis (commonly called tinea or ringworm) refers to infection of keratinized structures (the skin, hair, and nails) caused by a group of keratinophilic fungi, called the dermatophytes.

Dermatophytes are classified into 3 types:

  • Trichophyton infects skin, hair, and nails. The species include T. rubrum, T. mentagrophytes, T. tonsurans, T. schoenleinii, T. violaceum, etc. Microconidia > Macroconidia
  • Microsporum infects only hair and skin but, not the nails. The species include M. gypseum, M. canis, and M. nanum. Macroconidia> Microconidia.
  • Epidermophyton infects only skin and nails, not hair. Floccosum is the only species in this genus. Only Macroconidia.

Clinical features of infection by Microsporum include:

  • Skin lesions in the skin tend to be circular, dry, erythematous, scaly, and itchy.
  • Hair lesions include kerion, scarring, and alopecia.

Diagnosis is established by clinical features, the use of Wood's lamp, and laboratory investigations such as microscopic examination and culture characteristics.

Microscopic examination of material teased out from the fungal colony (culture mount) or material taken on cellotape (cellotape mount) is observed for identification of the species. It is observed for the presence and type of hyphae and conidia. Conidia (asexual spores) are of two types: small unicellular microconidia and larger septate macroconidia.

Related Pearl: Characteristic features of macroconidia and microconidia of dermatophytes

Dermatophyte  

Macroconidia

Microconidia

Trichophyton

Thin-walled, pencil-shaped

Small unicellular

Microsporum

Multicellular, spindle-shaped

Scanty

Epidermophyton

Multicellular, pear-shaped, arranged in clusters

Absent

Trichophyton

 

Microsporum

 

Epidermophyton

questions.text: A 21-year-old student presents with ocular redness, foreign body sensation, and excessive tearing following the use of a contact lens. An interface contrast microscopy from his corneal scraping is shown below. What would be the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history and the demonstration of polygonal cysts in interface contrast microscopy are suggestive of amoebic keratitis caused by acanthamoeba.

Acanthamoeba culbertsoni is an opportunistic protozoan pathogen. It exists as trophozoite form and resistant cystic form. Both these forms are infective. The trophozoite is large and characterized by spine-like pseudopodia (acanthopodia).

Human beings acquire the infection by inhalation of cysts or trophozoites, directly through traumatized skin or eyes, or ingestion of cysts.

It chiefly presents as two chronic conditions:

  • Acanthamoeba keratitis
  • Granulomatous amoebic encephalitis

Acanthamoeba keratitis is an infection of the eyes that typically develops from the entry of the amebic cyst through abrasions on the cornea. Most of the cases are associated with the use of contact lenses. 

Patients usually present with photophobia, excessive tearing, redness, and foreign body sensation and it can be bilateral in contact lens users.

Diagnosis of amoebic keratitis is made by the demonstration of the cyst in corneal scrapings by wet mount, histology, and culture. The cysts are smaller (12-25 micrometer) and polygonal or star-shaped.

Topical administration of biguanides or chlorhexidine with or without diamidine agents can be used for the management of acanthamoeba keratitis. In severe cases penetrating keratoplasty can be done.

The below image shows the ring lesion seen in acanthamoeba keratitis.

 

 

The below image shows cysts of acanthamoeba in lactophenol cotton blue staining.

Other options:

Option B- Naegleria fowleri causes a brain infection, primary amebic meningoencephalitis that leads to brain tissue destruction. Their cysts are spherical and have a smooth double wall. 

Option C- Entamoeba histolytica causes intestinal and extraintestinal amebiasis. Their cysts are spherical in shape. A mature quadrinucleate cyst is the infective form.  An amebic ulcer is a typical lesion seen in intestinal amebiasis which is a flask-shaped ulcer in cross-section. Amebic liver abscess is extraintestinal amebiasis which has a center of abscess that contains thick colored brown pus termed anchovy sauce pus.

Option D- Balamuthia mandrillaris is a free-living ameba that causes granulomatous amebic encephalitis. Their cyst is usually spherical and surrounded by a three-layered cyst wall.

questions.text:
In which of the following situations will you use a sanitizer?

A. Before examining the patient
B. After examining the patient
C. After touching the patient's surroundings
D. Hands are visibly soiled
questions.solution:
You should use sanitiser before and after examining the patient and after touching the patient's surroundings.

The most significant precaution that is effective in preventing infection transmission is hand hygiene. This is achieved by washing hands with soap and water and/or by hand rubbing with alcohol or non-alcohol-based hand sanitizer. The most effective and least expensive way is by washing hands before and after any patient interaction.

Perform hand hygiene

  • When hands are visibly soiled.
  • After barehanded touching of instruments, equipment, materials, and other objects likely to be contaminated by blood, saliva, or respiratory secretions.
  • Before and after treating each patient.
  • Before putting on gloves and again immediately after removing gloves.

First use soap and water when hands are visibly soiled (e.g., blood, body fluids). When they are not soiled, an alcohol-based hand rub may be used.

Disinfectants like chlorhexidine and alexidine have a biguanide functional group. They are mostly used as oral disinfectants and hand products. They are bactericidal but not sporicidal. Mycobacteria are also resistant to these compounds.

Related Pearl: Methods of Sterilization and Disinfection

  Spectrum Uses
1. Heat    
Hot air oven All Glasswares, sterilizing powders, oils, swabs and dressings
Autoclaving All Linen, surgical instruments, laboratory ware, media and pharmaceutical products
Boiling Most pathogens, some spores Metal tools, rubber or plastic equipment, cloth 
Pasteurization Vegetative bacteria Beverages, plastic hospital equipment
2. Ethylene oxide gas All Heat-sensitive equipment like heart-lung machines, artificial valves, fabrics, respirators, cardiac catheters, books
3. Radiation    
UV All Limited value due to poor penetration, can be used for plastic syringes, catheters, and laboratory cabinets
Ionising All Surgical supplies, food
4. Chemicals    
Alcohol Vegetative bacteria, viruses some spores Skin disinfection, hand washing
Hydrogen peroxide Viruses, vegetative bacteria, spores and fungi High-level disinfectant, antiseptic for wounds and discharging ulcers
Chlorine Viruses, vegetative bacteria, fungi To disinfect water
Iodophors Viruses, vegetative bacteria, fungi, lethal to spore-bearing organisms Skin disinfection, disinfect blood culture bottles and medical equipment
Crude phenol Gram-positive and gram-negative bacteria, but only slowly effective against spores and acid-fast bacteria. Disinfection of faeces, mopping floors and cleaning drains.
5. Glutaraldehyde   All Endoscopes, bronchoscopes
6. Quarternary ammonium compounds Most bacteria, fungi, lipophilic viruses  General cleaning

questions.text: Which of the following organism is not a cause of atypical pneumonia?
questions.solution:
Among the given organisms, Streptococcus pneumoniae is not a cause of atypical pneumonia

Pneumonia due to Mycoplasma pneumonia (Eaton agent), Chlamydia and Legionella are considered atypical pneumonia. Where as Streptococcus pneumoniae caused typical pneumonia in the form of lobar pneumonia

The below chest X-ray shows patchy consolidation at the hilum and fanning to the periphery.

Related Pearl: Typical Pneumonia v/s Atypical Pneumonia

Typical pneumonia  Atypical pneumonia 
Extracellular organism  Intracellular organism
Alveolar exudates in air spaces Interstitial involvement
Neutrophilic in nature Lymphocytic in nature
High-grade fever Low-grade fever
Productive cough Dry cough
Causes hemoptysis Only scanty sputum
Pleuritic chest pain Extrapulmonary manifestation
X-Ray shows large areas of consolidation X-Ray shows an Interstitial pattern of involvement.

Remember

  • The most common cause of Community-acquired Pneumonia- Streptococcus pneumoniae.
  • The most common cause of Atypical Pneumonia- Mycoplasma pneumoniae.
  • The most common cause of Nosocomial Pneumonia- Overall, gram-negative bacilli are more commonly implicated as a group; however, the single most common agent is Staphylococcus aureus (i.e., gram-positive cocci)

questions.text: Which of the following reactions are positive for Clostridium perfringens
questions.solution:
Target hemolysis and reverse CAMP test are positive for Clostridium perfringens.

A narrow zone of complete hemolysis due to theta toxin and a wider zone of incomplete hemolysis due to alpha toxin results in target hemolysis on blood agar.

In reverse CAMP test, C.perfringens is streaked over the centre of the plate, Streptococcus agalactiae is streaked at right angles to it. A positive reverse CAMP test shows the presence of an arrow-shaped zone of enhanced hemolysis pointing towards C.perfringens. Alpha toxin produced by Clostridium perfringens interacts with CAMP factor and produce synergistic hemolysis.

 

M'fadyean reaction is positive Bacillus anthracis.

The CAMP test is positive for Streptococcus agalactiae where it is inoculated on a plate streaked with Staphylococcus aureus.

Elek's test is positive for Corynebacterium diptheriae.

questions.text: A 24-year-old female presents with a history of progressive breathlessness and difficulty in breathing since 3 months. A chest X-ray shows a cavitary lesion in the lower lobe of the lung. Lobectomy was done and the histopathology image is given below. What is the most probable causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the histological slide are suggestive of hydatid disease of the lung caused by Echinococcus granulosus.

Hydatid disease most commonly occurs in the liver, the second most common being the lungs. The clinical features of hydatid disease of the lung include breathlessness, cough, hemoptysis, chest pain, and even pneumothorax. Treatment includes wedge resection or lobectomy and administration of albendazole. Pre and postoperative chemotherapy with albendazole is recommended for 2 years after curative surgery.

Casoni’s test is a type I hypersensitivity reaction used in the diagnosis of hydatid disease. It involves the intradermal injection of 0.25 ml of sterilized fluid from hydatid cysts/human cysts on the forearm. An equal volume of saline is injected into the other forearm as control. It is observed for the next 30 minutes and again after 1-2 days. The fluid used for the test is sterilized by Seitz filtration. A wheal response at the injection site occurring within 20 minutes is considered positive. It is followed by a secondary reaction 8 hours later. The test is not often used nowadays due to its non-specificity.

The hydatid cyst wall consists of 3 layers:

  • Pericyst- the outer dense fibrous capsule that is formed as a result of host inflammatory response.
  • Ectocyst- the intermediate layer consisting of acellular, chitinous, laminated hyaline material.
  • Endocyst- the inner germinal layer that is cellular and consists of a number of nuclei embedded in protoplasmic mass and is extremely thin. It is the vital layer of the cyst and it is the site of asexual reproduction giving rise to brood capsules with scolices.

The below image shows the histology of hydatid cyst.

questions.text: A patients plasma has high levels of interferon beta. He most likely has an infection due to _____ ?
questions.solution:
Interferon beta is secreted during infection due to viruses. It is produced by fibroblasts. 

Types of interferons: 

  • Alpha Interferon (Leukocyte interferon) is produced by leucocytes. It has antiviral activity. 
  • Beta Interferon (Fibroblast interferon) is produced by fibroblasts and epithelial cells. It has antiviral activity. 
  • Gamma Interferon (Immune interferon) is produced by T-lymphocytes. It is concerned with immuno-modulatory and anti-proliferative functions.

questions.text:
Which of the following are acid-fast staining organisms?
  1. Nocardia
  2. Actinomyces
  3. Mycobacterium leprae
  4. Clostridium perfringens
  5. Corynebacterium diphtheriae
  6. Isospora belli
questions.solution:
Nocardia, Mycobacterium leprae, and Cytoisospora belli are acid-fast staining organisms.

Acid-fast staining is based on the principle that tubercle bacilli resist decolourization with acids after staining with aniline dyes. Acid fastness is attributed to the variety of fatty acids, alcohols, and lipids in the tubercle bacilli. Acid-fast organisms usually contain mycolic acid, which is acid-fast in the free state.  The steps to carry out acid-fast staining as modified by Ziehl and Neelsen are:

  1. The slide is stained with carbolfuchsin along with the application of heat.
  2. It is then decolourized with 20% sulphuric acid. Later methylene blue is used for counterstaining.
  3. The acid-fast bacteria retain the fuchsin colour, while other organisms take up the counterstain.

The genus Nocardia are aerobic organisms and weakly acid-fast positive rods. They stain with carbolfuchsin and retain it when 1-4% sulfuric acid is used.

 

Mycobacterium leprae, the causative agent of leprosy is a gram-positive bacillus. It is acid-fast when 5% sulphuric acid is used instead of 20%.

 

Cryptosporidium parvum, commonly causes diarrhea in immunocompromised individuals. The oocysts in the stool can be visualized by modified Ziehl-Neelsen staining. It appears as red acid-fast spheres. It can also be used for specimens such as sputum and bronchial wash.

 

Isospora belli is a coccidian parasite that can cause protracted diarrhea in immunocompromised patients. Modified Ziehl-Neelsen staining reveals pink-colored acid-fast oocyst in stool samples.

 

Actinomyces are gram-positive, anaerobic, and filamentous bacteria that are non-acid-fast in contrast to Nocardia.

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains

These include eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, congo red, etc.

Used to stain pathological specimens
Basic stains.

Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction.
Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, M. avium, Nocardia etc.
Fluorochrome staining: Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains:

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor white staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain calcofluor white. It is especially useful for the identification of mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.  It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For cell wall demonstration

questions.text: Which of the following complement deficiency leads to an increased risk of Neisseria meningitidis infection?
questions.solution:
Complements C5-C9 deficiency (Terminal complement pathway deficiency) increases the risk of disseminated Neisseria meningitidis infection.

Complement protein deficiency Diseases associated
C1, C2, C4 Immune-complex disease (Eg:SLE)
C3, Factor I Susceptibility to capsulated bacteria
C5-C9 Susceptibility to Neisseria
Factor D. properdin (factor P) Susceptibility to capsulated bacteria and Neisseria.

DAF (Decay accelerating factor)

CD 59

 Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria
C1 esterase inhibitor Hereditary angioneurotic edema(HAE)

questions.text: Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome is caused by
questions.solution:
Waterhouse-Friderichsen Syndrome also known as hemorrhagic adrenalitis or fulminant meningococcemia is a complication seen in infection with meningococci, characterized by bilateral adrenal gland hemorrhage.

Complications : 

  • Shock, extensive haemorrhage within the skin and fall into coma.
  • Death usually after a few hours, adrenal insufficiency being the immediate cause.

TREATMENT

  • Fulminant meningococcemia is a medical emergency and needs to be treated with adequate antibiotics as fast as possible.
  • Ceftriaxone is an antibiotic commonly employed today.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy returned from a birthday party and began vomiting 4-5 hours later, followed by a few episodes of loose stools but had no fever. Other children who had attended the party reported a similar illness. Food samples were collected and sent for toxin detection by a test based on the following principle. This test is known as:
questions.solution:
The given image shows Sandwich ELISA. The above clinical scenario is suggestive of food poisoning caused by Staphylococcus aureus.

The symptoms of food poisoning caused by S aureus appear within 1-8 hours. Multiple people are exposed to the pathogen from a common source and present with vomiting, loose stools but no fever. Foods from outbreaks of food poisoning is examined for the presence of staphylococcal enterotoxin A (SEA) by a sandwich ELISA.

ELISA (Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay) involves the use of an immunosorbent, which is an absorbing material that is specific for one of the components of the reaction, either the antigen or antibody. This may be a particulate phase (cellulose or agarose), or a solid phase (polystyrene, polyvinyl, or polycarbonate tubes or microwells). ELISA is done using 96-well microtitre plates suitable for automation.

Sandwich ELISA is used for antigen detection in the patient samples. The antigen is sandwiched between two layers of antibodies - capture and detection antibodies.

The following steps are followed in Sandwich ELISA:

  1. The capture antibody is immobilized on a microtiter well.
  2. A sample containing antigen is added and allowed to react with the immobilized antibody.
  3. After the well is washed, a second enzyme-linked antibody (Detecting antibody) specific to the antigen is added and allowed to react with the bound antigen.
  4. After any free second antibody is removed by washing, the substrate is added. This substrate is converted by the enzyme to detectable colored form and the colored reaction product is measured.

Other options:

Cassette ELISA: Here, each specimen is tested in a separate disposable cassette and gives rapid results (10-15 minutes). There is no need for microplate washers or readers and the result can be read visually. Example: Dot Blot Assay used for the detection of HIV type 1 and 2 antibodies.

Competitive ELISA: Both the unknown antigen (sample) and the known antigen (standard) compete with each other for a fixed amount of antibody.

Indirect ELISA: Antibody in the sample can be detected or quantitatively measured using this method. Serum or some other sample containing primary antibody (Ab1) is added to an antigen-coated microtiter well and allowed to react. Enzyme-conjugated secondary anti-isotype antibody (Ab2) is added which binds to the primary antibody.

The given image shows steps followed in different types of ELISA.

questions.text: Two days after penicillin administration, a patient developed antibodies that resulted in hemolysis. Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is this?
questions.solution:
Development of antibodies resulting in hemolysis after penicillin administration is an example of a type II reaction. This is a drug-induced type II hypersensitivity reaction.

Penicillin in high doses can result in immune-mediated hemolysis via the hapten mechanism. In this, the drug attaches to surface of RBC membrane. Antibodies are produced that are targeted against this combination of penicillin and RBCs. 

Complement is activated by the attached antibody leading to the removal of red blood cells by the spleen.

Related Pearl: Types of Type II Antibody-Mediated Hypersensitivity

There are 3 mechanisms involved in type 2 hypersensitivity reactions- 

  1. Antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction- antibodies react with antigens present on cell surfaces or in the extracellular matrix cause disease by destroying these cells, triggering inflammation, or interfering with normal functions
    1. Myasthenia gravis (against acetylcholine receptor)
    2. Graves’ disease (against TSH receptor)
    3. Pemphigus Vulgaris (against epidermal cadherin)
    4. Pernicious anemia (against intrinsic factor)
    5. Insulin resistant diabetes (against insulin receptor
  2. Antibody-mediated opsonization and phagocytosis -antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement and Recruiting Phagocytes
    1. Transfusion reactions
    2. Erythroblastosis fetalis
    3. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
    4. Autoimmune thrombocytopenic purpura
  3. Complement and Fc receptor-mediated inflammation- antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement
    1. Goodpasture syndrome
    2. Vasculitis due to ANCA
    3. Acute rheumatic fever
    4. Vascular rejection in organ graft

questions.text: A 2 year old child is brought to the OPD with oral and perioral lesions as seen in the image below. Similar lesions were also found on his palms and soles. What is the probable causative organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image are suggestive of hand, foot, and mouth disease that is caused by coxsackie A virus.

Hand, foot, and mouth disease initially begins with fever and sore throat following which blisters develop over the oral cavity, hands and feet.

It usually occurs in children but may also occur in adults. It is a self limiting disease and subsides in 1-2 weeks.

The following images show lesions affecting hands and feet:

Other options:

Option B: Molluscum contagiosum presents as umbilicated nodules and not vesicles.

Option C: Parvovirus B19 infection occurs usually in children 5–10 years causing erythema infectiosum. It is also known as fifth disease. It begins as a prominent erythema of the cheeks- slapped cheek disease, spreading to the trunk and limbs, followed by lymphadenopathy and arthralgia

Option D: Streptococcus causes red sores around the mouth and the nose in impetigo. It forms a characteristic honey-coloured scab and is not associated with lesions on palms and soles. The given image shows impetigo.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used as an immediate test in the screening of urinary tract infections (UTI)?
questions.solution:
Pour plate culture (quantitative test) is not used as an immediate test for screening of UTI. However it is considered the best diagnostic test for confirmation of UTI due it’s high sensitivity and specificity.

The screening tests for UTI are as follows:

  • Wet mount examination: It is done to demonstrate pus cells in urine. 
  • Leukocyte esterase test: It is a rapid and cheaper method, and detects leukocyte esterases secreted by pus cells present in urine.
  • Nitrate reduction test (Griess test): Nitrate reducing bacteria like E. coli give a positive result.
  • Catalase test: E. coli and other bacteria that produce the enzyme catalase give a positive result.

Quantitative Culture:

  • Standardized loop technique
  • Pour plate method

questions.text: A microbiologist performs the following test and observes swelling of the capsule. In which of the following organisms will this phenomenon not be observed in?
questions.solution:
The given image shows Quellung reaction and is seen in capsulated bacteria. Neisseria gonorrhoeae is not capsulated, therefore Quellung reaction will not be observed in it. 

In Quellung reaction, a suspension of a capsulated bacterium is mixed with its specific anticapsular serum and examined under the microscope, the capsule becomes very prominent and appears swollen.

Mnemonic for capsulated organisms:

Some- Streptococcus pneumoniae

Killers- Klebsiella pneumoniae

Have- Haemophilus influenzae

Nice- Neisseria meningitidis

Capsules- Cryptococcus neoformans

Related Pearl: Types of capsules in microorganisms

Capsule  Organsim
Polysaccharide capsule 

 Streptococcus pneumonia

 Klebsiella pneumonia

 Hemophilius influenza

 Neiserria meningitidis

 Salmonella typhi

 Cryptococcus neoformans

 Bordetella pertussis

Clostridium perfringens
Hyaluronic acid capsule  Streptococcus pyogenes
Polypeptide (Poly-D -Glutamate) Capsule  Bacillus anthracis
F1 Protein Capsule  Yersinia pestis

questions.text: Which of the following virus is bullet shaped?
questions.solution:
The virus with a bullet shape is the rabies virus. Rabies viruses belonging to the family Rhabdoviridae are bullet-shaped viruses with nonsegmented single-stranded RNA.

 

 

Option B: Corona virus belonging to the family are crown-shaped viruses with nonsegmented single-stranded RNA. Coronavirus has petal/club-shaped peplomers radiating like sun rays.

 

Option C: Rotaviruses appear as cartwheel-shaped structures with short spokes radiating from them. 11 segments of double-stranded RNA constitute the genome.

 

Option D - The influenza virus is a linear, segmented, single-stranded RNA. 

The influenza virus contains two surface antigens:

  • Hemagglutinin (HA) - causes RBC agglutination; facilitates viral entry into cells. Elution is the process of reversal of hemagglutination and the release of the virus from the red cell surface.
  • Neuraminidase (NA) - an enzyme that destroys the receptor HA uses to bind to RBCs causing elution/reversal of hemagglutination. Hence, it is also called a receptor-destroying enzyme (RDE).

Reassortment of the genome occurs readily due to the presence of this segmented RNA.

Related Pearl: Important Shapes of Some Viruses

VIRUS

SHAPE

Rabies virus

Bullet shaped

Pox virus

Brick shaped

Tobacco mosaic virus

Rod shaped

Ebola virus

Filamentous

Astro virus

Star shaped

Adenovirus

Space vehicle shaped

Rotavirus

Wheel shaped

questions.text: A patient presented with a high fever, altered sensorium, headache, neck rigidity, and seizures. He was diagnosed with HSV encephalitis. Which of the following tests can be used to confirm the diagnosis?

choices.text: CSF culture on chick embryo lines

questions.solution:
HSV-DNA demonstration in CSF by PCR is the investigation of choice for HSV encephalitis. 

Herpes simplex virus (HSV) encephalitis is defined as inflammation of brain parenchyma caused by the herpes virus, and it typically presents as an acute febrile illness.

Patients typically present with acute onset of fever, altered levels of consciousness, personality changes, and evidence of either focal or diffuse neurologic signs and symptoms, especially in the temporal lobe. Focal or generalized seizures occur in many patients with HSV encephalitis. Other most commonly encountered focal findings include aphasia, ataxia, upper motor neuron or lower motor neuron type lesions, and cranial nerve deficits.

HSV-DNA demonstration in CSF by PCR is the investigation of choice for HSV encephalitis. Other investigations that can help include CSF examination, CSF culture, serological studies, MRI, CT, EEG, and brain biopsy.

The T2-weighted MRI of the brain will show hyperintensity in the temporal lobe in most of the patients. Bilateral involvement of the temporal lobe is more common in HSV encephalitis.

The image below is a coronal T2-weighted MR image showing a high signal intensity in the temporal lobes in a patient with HSV encephalitis.

Management includes supportive therapy (monitoring of intracranial pressure, fluid restriction, avoidance of hypotonic IV fluids), anticonvulsants for seizures, and intravenous acyclovir is beneficial in the treatment of HSV encephalitis.

 Other options:

Option A: IgM antibodies in CSF - Serological tests to detect antibodies are used for primary herpes infections.

Option B: Tzanck smear of CSF - A positive smear shows multinucleated giant cells with faceted nuclei and ground glass appearance. It is a rapid, inexpensive, and fairly sensitive diagnostic test. The Tzanck smear is typically used to diagnose cutaneous herpes infections, such as herpes simplex or varicella-zoster virus. It is not an appropriate diagnostic test for HSV encephalitis, as it does not provide definitive confirmation of the presence of HSV in the CSF.

Option D: CSF culture in chick embryos - It is not a sensitive test used for the diagnosis of HSV encephalitis. Negative CSF viral cultures have no value in ruling out HSV encephalitis. Although this method can be used to isolate HSV, it is not as sensitive or specific as PCR for viral DNA and it can take a longer time to obtain results.

questions.text: A child presented with umbilicated pearly white nodules in the skin. Which of the following will be seen on biopsy of these lesions?
questions.solution:
The lesions in this child are suggestive of Molluscum contagiosum virus infection. They show Henderson-Paterson bodies.

Double-stranded DNA virus causes molluscum contagiosum. Lesions are firm, white to flesh-coloured, dome-shaped, pearly nodules, having a central umbilication from which one can express a cheesy material.

Inclusion bodies are the most characteristic histological features seen in virus-infected cells. Inclusion bodies can be demonstrated under a light microscope. 

Inclusion bodies can be situated in the:

  • Cytoplasm as in poxviruses, rabies. 
  • Nucleus as in herpesviruses
  • Both cytoplasm and nucleus as in the measles virus

Inclusion bodies are generally acidophilic and appear as pink structures when stained with Giemsa stain or eosin methylene blue but some viruses like adenovirus have basophilic inclusions. 

Other options:

Option A- In measles, infected cells show acidophilic nuclear and cytoplasmic inclusions. The lymphoid tissues of measles patients show multinucleated giant cells named Warthin-Finkeldey cells. 

Option C- Vaccinia-infected cells have small multiple-inclusion bodies named Guarnieri bodies. 

Option D- In rabies-infected brain cells, intracytoplasmic eosinophilic inclusions named Negri bodies are seen.

Related Pearl: Inclusion bodies seen in various conditions/diseases

1. Bacterial Inclusion Bodies 

Disease/Bacteria  Inclusion bodies 
Granuloma inguinale, Klebsiella granulomatis Donovan bodies
Psittacosis, Chlamydia psittacci  Levinthal-Cole-Lille bodies (LCL bodies)
Trachoma, Chlamydia trachomatis Halberstaedter-Prowazek bodies
Lymphogranuloma venereum, Chlamydia trachomatis Miyagawa’s granulocorpusles
Diphtheria, Corynebacterium diptheriae Babes-Ernst granules

 

2. Viral Inclusion Bodies

  • Intra-cytoplasmic Inclusion Bodies
Disease/Virus Inclusion bodies
Rabies Negri bodies
Vaccinia, variola (smallpox) Guarnieri bodies
Variola (smallpox) Paschen bodies
Molluscum contagiosum Henderson-Patterson bodies
Fowlpox Bollinger bodies
  • Intra-nuclear Inclusion Bodies 
  Inclusion bodies  Disease/Virus
Cowdry type A Lipschutz inclusions Herpes Virus
Torres bodies Yellow fever
Cowdry type B Basophilic inclusions Adenovirus
Acidophilic inclusions Poliovirus
  • Both Intra-nuclear and Intra-cytoplasmic Inclusion Bodies 
Disease/Virus  Inclusion bodies 
Measles Virus Warthin-Finkedly giant cells
Cytomegalovirus Owl-eye inclusions (basophilic, predominantly intra-nuclear, small granular intracytoplasmic inclusions are found)

 

3. Inclusion Bodies in Parasitic Infections 

Disease/Parasite Inclusion bodies 
Trypanosomiasis Morula cells with IgM Deposits
Kala-azar Leishman-Donovan Bodies

 

4. Miscellaneous Inclusion Bodies 

Disease/Location Inclusion bodies 
Ovarian cortex Walthard Inclusions
Spherical globules surrounded by granulosa cells in the ovary Call-Exner bodies
Parkinsonism, Lewy body dementia  Lewy Bodies
Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis  Bunina bodies
Multiple Myeloma Russell Bodies

questions.text: The 8-year-old child with delayed development, whose picture is given below, was referred for evaluation of recurrent infections. History is notable for the presence of congenital heart defects. Further examination reveals the presence of a cleft palate and workup reveals the presence of hypocalcemia.  Which component of the immune system is likely to be affected in this child?
questions.solution:
The clinical features point towards the diagnosis of DiGeorge syndrome. Cell-mediated immunity is affected in DiGeorge syndrome.

DiGeorge syndrome is a complex embryopathy with an autosomal dominant inheritance that is caused by microdeletions in chromosome 22, leading to multiple developmental defects (involving the 3rd and 4th pharyngeal pouches), including hypoparathyroidism, and dysmorphic facies.

Children with DiGeorge syndrome are born without a thymus and therefore lack the T-cell component of the cell-mediated immune system. The disease may range from mildly increased susceptibility to infections to a severe disease requiring thymic or hematopoietic stem cell transplant. Patients are generally able to cope with extracellular bacterial infections because their innate and T cell-independent antibody responses are intact, but they cannot effectively eliminate intracellular pathogens such as viruses, intracellular bacteria, and fungi.

The clinical features of this syndrome include:

  • Congenital heart disease- aortic arch anomalies
  • Abnormalities of the palate like cleft palate.
  • Facial dysmorphism such as hypertelorism, antimongoloid slant, low set ears, micrognathia, short philtrum, bifid uvula.
  • Thymic hypoplasia with impaired T cell immunity. 
  • Parathyroid hypoplasia resulting in hypocalcemia (tetany).

questions.text: A pregnant woman who underwent syphilis testing showed positive results for VDRL but negative for specific treponemal tests. Interpret the results
questions.solution:
This pregnant woman with a positive VDRL and negative for specific treponemal tests is most likely to have a biological false positive test.

 The serological tests for syphilis use either nontreponemal or treponemal antigens.

  • Nontreponemal tests- Are used as screening tests for syphilis and follow the efficacy of therapy. They are not very sensitive in early syphilis, and false-positive results can occur with many other diseases. Examples- VDRL(Venereal Disease Research Laboratory) and RPR (Rapid plasma reagin).
  • Treponemal antibody tests- Are used to confirm if a positive result from a nontreponemal test is truly positive or falsely positive. They are less useful as screening tests because once positive after initial syphilitic infection the tests remain positive for life independent of therapy for syphilis. Examples- T. pallidum–particle agglutination(TPPA)test, Fluorescent treponemal antibody absorbed (FTA-ABS), etc.

Related Pearl: Biological False Positive reactions in serologic testing of syphilis

Acute biological false-positive reactions are seen in (<6 months):

  • Pregnancy
  • Upper respiratory tract infections
  • Measles
  • Chickenpox
  • Hepatitis
  • Viral pneumonia
  • Malaria 
  • Following vaccination and immunization
  • Lymphogranuloma venereum
  • Chancroid
  • Tuberculosis
  • Pneumococcal pneumonia
  • Leptospirosis

Chronic biological false-positive reactions are seen in (>6 months):  

  • Leprosy
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Rheumatic fever
  • Polyarteritis nodosa
  • Leukemia
  • Pernicious anemia
  • Metastatic carcinoma

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the OPD with complaints of fever chills, abdominal pain, and diarrhoea. He gives a history of consuming raw refrigerated cucumbers the previous day. What is the most likely etiologic organism?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture is suggestive of food poisoning caused by Listeria monocytogenes.

It can survive at refrigerator temperatures (4°C), under conditions of low pH and high salt. So it is able to overcome food preservation and safety barriers, making it an important foodborne pathogen.

Healthy persons exposed to L. monocytogenes in food may not become ill or may develop a mild, self-limiting febrile gastroenteritis lasting 1–3 days. Symptoms include fever, chills, headache, myalgias, abdominal pain, and diarrhea. Infection of pregnant women may lead to abortion or stillbirth. It may cause meningitis or sepsis in neonates due to perinatal transmission through an infected birth canal. Immunocompromised individuals can develop Listeria meningoencephalitis, bacteremia, and (rarely) focal infections.

The drug of choice is high dose intravenous ampicillin.

Related Pearl: Food Poisoning

Organism Symptoms Common food source
1-6 hrs incubation period  
Staphylococcus aureus Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea Ham, poultry, potato, cream pastries, mayonnaise
Bacillus cereus Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea Fried rice
8-16 hrs incubation period  
Clostridium perfringes Abdominal cramps, diarrhea Beef, poultry, legume, gravies
Bacillus cereus Abdominal cramps, diarrhea Meat, vegetables, dried beans, cereals
>16 hrs incubation period  
Vibrio cholerae Watery diarrhea Shellfish, water
Salmonella species Inflammatory diarrhea Beef, poultry, eggs
Enterotoxigenic E.coli Watery diarrhea Salads, cheese, meats
Enterohemorrhagic E.coli Bloody diarrhea Raw milk, raw vegetables, apple juice
Campylobacter jejuni Inflammatory diarrhea Poultry, raw milk
Shigella species Dysentery Potato, egg salad, lettuce
Vibrio parahemolyticus Dysentery Molluscs, crustaceans

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with fever, sore throat, and dyspnea. The findings of oral cavity examination are shown below. What is the mechanism of action of the toxin produced by the causative organism?
questions.solution:
This child with pseudomembrane over tonsil has diphtheria, in which the toxin inactivates the elongation factor EF-2.

Diphtheria toxin is an exotoxin that consists of two fragments - A and B. It acts by inhibiting protein synthesis. Fragment B helps in binding the toxin to the cells while fragment A inactivates the elongation factor (EF-2) responsible for protein synthesis. Pseudomonas aeruginosa also produces toxins with a similar mechanism of action.

This infection presents as fever and sore throat, which progresses to dyspnea due to obstruction by the pseudomembrane. Bull's neck appearance is seen due to cervical lymphadenitis. Complications like damage to the heart (myocarditis), kidney (tubular necrosis), liver, and adrenal glands can develop due to the toxin.

Neisser's or Albert's stain will show the bacilli with metachromatic granules situated at the poles of the bacilli. Tellurite blood agar is the selective culture medium.

It is treated mainly by neutralizing with antitoxin and antibiotics to arrest more toxin production.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins

The mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins are as given below:

Increase in cAMP

  • Bordetella pertusis
  • Bacillus anthracis
  • Vibrio cholerae - Cholera toxin
  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat labile toxin

Increase in cGMP

  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat stable toxin

Inhibition of protein synthesis

  • Diptheria toxin: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Pseudomonas: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Clostridium difficile
  • Enterohemorrhagic E.coli (EHEC)-Shiga-like toxin: inhibit 60S
  • Shigella dysenteriae- Shiga toxin: inhibit 60S

questions.text: Which of the following drugs acts on the following stage of malarial parasite?
questions.solution:
The above image shows banana shaped gametocyte stage of Plasmodium Falciparum.

The antimalarial drugs which have gametocidal properties include chloroquine and primaquine.

Primaquine is used for 14 days as a tissue schizonticide for the purpose of reducing the likelihood of relapse due to hypnozoites of Plasmodium vivax and Plasmodium ovale. It is also a potent gametocidal drug and is given as a single dose on day 2 for its gametocidal property in Plasmodium Falciparum.

Chloroquine acts primarily against erythrocytic asexual stages, although it has gametocidal properties.

Related Pearl: Treatment of Malaria

 

Drug of Choice

 Primaquine Dose

P. vivax malaria

Chloroquine 25 mg/kg divided as:

10mg/kg on day 1

10mg/kg on day 2

5mg/kg on day 3

0.25 mg/kg for 14 days

P. falciparum malaria

North East

In other states

 

ACT-AL for 3 days

ACT-SP for 3 days 

 

0.75mg/kg on day 2

0.75mg/kg on day 2

Mixed infection

North East

In other states

ACT-AL for 3 days

ACT-SP for 3 days

 

0.25 mg/kg for 14 days

0.25 mg/kg for 14 days

Resistance to ACT/ Severe malaria

 

Quinine

 

-

Pregnancy

P. vivax

Chloroquine

Contraindicated

Pregnancy

P. falciparum

1st trimester: Quinine

2nd and 3rd trimester: Area specific ACT

 

Contraindicated

ACT: artemisinin-based combination therapy

AL: artemether-lumefantrine

SP: Sulfadoxine-Pyrimethamine

questions.text:
Match the respective organisms with their periodicity.
1. Wuchereria bancrofti a. Diurnal
2. Loa loa b. Nocturnal
3. Onchocerca volvulus c. Nonperiodic
4.  Brugia malayi
questions.solution:
1. Wuchereria bancrofti b. Nocturnal 
2. Loa loa a. Diurnal
3. Onchocerca volvulus c. Nonperiodic
4.  Brugia malayi b. Nocturnal

The microfilariae are found in large numbers in the peripheral blood during specific times of the day, depending on the blood-feeding habits of their insect vector. This is known as periodicity. Filarial worms can exhibit nocturnal, diurnal periodicity, or no periodicity at all.

  • Nocturnal periodicity: When the largest number of microfilariae are present in the blood at night. Eg- Wuchereria bancrofti, Brugia malayi, Brugia timori
  • Diurnal periodicity: When the largest number of microfilariae occur in blood during the day. Eg- Loa loa
  • Nonperiodic: When the number of microfilariae maintains a constant level during the day and night. Eg- Onchocerca volvulus
  • Subperiodic or nocturnally subperiodic: When the microfilariae can be detected in the blood throughout the day but are detected in larger numbers in the late afternoon or at night. Eg- Wuchereria bancrofti in the eastern Pacific and Brugia malayi in Indonesia and southeast Asia.

questions.text: Which of the following infection is caused by the organism shown below?
questions.solution:
The given image shows  spherical and terminal spores with a drumstick appearance suggestive of Clostridium tetani. It causes tetany. 

  • The genus Clostridium consists of gram-positive, anaerobic, spore-forming bacilli.
  • The spores are wider than the bacillary bodies, giving the bacillus a swollen appearance, resembling a spindle. Hence, the name Clostridium.

The shape and position of spores vary in different species and these are used in the identification and classification of Clostridium as follows:

  1. Central or equatorial:  Clostridium bifermentans
  2. Subterminal: Clostridium perfringens, Clostridium novyi, and Clostridium botulinum
  3. Oval and terminal (tennis racket shaped): Clostridium tertium and Clostridium difficle
  4. Spherical and terminal (drumstick appearance): Clostridium tetani

The image given below shows Corynebacterium diphtheriae which causes diphtheria.

 

The image given below shows subterminal spores that can be seen in Clostridium perfringens and Clostridium botulinum which cause gas gangrene and botulism respectively.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best diagnostic method to diagnose typhoid after starting antibiotics?
questions.solution:
The best diagnostic method to diagnose typhoid after starting antibiotics is a bone marrow culture.

Enteric fever (typhoid fever) is caused by Salmonella species. The patient presents with stepladder pyrexia (fever), abdominal pain, diarrhoea, headache, and malaise.

Diagnosis of enteric fever:

  • Blood culture: It is more sensitive during 1st week. It rapidly becomes negative on treatment with antibiotics.

  • Antibody testing: WIDAL test to detect rising titers of H and O agglutinins against salmonella typhi and paratyphi. Agglutinins appear by the end of the first week and rise steadily up to the 3rd or 4th week, after which they disappear.

  • Stool culture: It yields positive results from the 3rd week onwards.

  • Urine culture: Results may be positive after the 2nd week.

  • Bone marrow culture remains positive for 5 days even after the start of antibiotics and is the most sensitive test in the first week. The culture of duodenal aspirate may yield positive results when bone marrow culture is inconclusive.
Widal Test: This is a test for the measurement of H and O agglutinins for typhoid and paratyphoid bacilli in the patient's serum. In this test, the agglutination titer depends on the stage of the disease. It is performed by mixing equal volumes (0.4 ml) of serial dilutions of the serum (from 1/10 to 1/640) with fixed volumes of H and O antigens in the Dreyer's and Felix agglutination tubes, respectively. These tubes are incubated overnight and the agglutination titres are read. H agglutination leads to the formation of cotton woolly clumps while O agglutination is seen as a disc-like pattern at the bottom of the tube.
The antigens used in Widal's test include:
  • O antigens of S. typhi (TO)
  • H antigens of S. typhi (TH)
  • H antigens of S. paratyphi A (AH)
  • H antigens of S. paratyphi B (BH)

Interpretation: 

  • The agglutination titer will depend on the stage of the disease:
    • Agglutinins usually appear by the end of the first week. 
    • The titer increases steadily till the third or fourth week, after which it declines gradually.
  • The H agglutinins persist longer than O agglutinins.
    • H antibodies appear earliest after infection and persist for several months.
    • The O antibodies follow the appearance of H antibodies and disappear in a few weeks. 
  • The 4-fold rise in titers between 1st and 3rd week is highly significant as compared to a single high titer:
    • This is because, in persons with a prior enteric fever, there is a transient rise of titer due to unrelated infections (malaria, dengue), known as an anamnestic reaction.
    • Therefore, after a one-week interval, if the titer increases, it indicates true infection. If the titer decreases, it indicates an anamnestic reaction. 
  • Cases treated early with antibiotics may show poor agglutinin response.
  • Interpretation of Widal test: 
    • Demonstration of a rise in titre of antibodies by testing two or more serum samples is more meaningful than a single test.
    • H agglutinin titer > 1/160 and O agglutinin titer >1/80 is considered significant.

questions.text: Identify the class of immunoglobulin​ shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
The above image shows a dimeric structure, characteristic of secretory IgA.

IgA immunoglobulin is the major antibody responsible for mucosal immunity. Its serum levels are usually low. It is predominantly present in the extravascular secretions. It is present in secretions such as milk, saliva, and tears, and in secretions of the respiratory, intestinal, and genital tracts.

When present in the serum, it exists as a monomer similar to IgG. However, when it is secreted, it exists as a dimer. The dimeric structure consists of two monomers, which are stabilized by two additional polypeptides:

  • J chain, which stabilizes the molecule.
  • Secretory component, which is incorporated into the IgA when transported through the epithelial cell.

Related Pearl: Properties of immunoglobulin classes

IgG:

  • Half-life- 23 days
  • Appears late, indicates chronic infection
  • It is the only maternal Ig to cross the placenta.
  • Has 4 subclasses.
  • Causes complement fixation, precipitation, and neutralization of toxins and virus.

IgM:

  • Half-life- 5 days
  • Has the highest molecular weight and is a pentamer.
  • Polysaccharides and lipids mainly stimulate IgM secretion.
  • Intravascular distribution.
  • Appears early, indicates recent infection.
  • Acts as surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.
  • It causes agglutination, hemolysis, and opsonization.

IgD:

  • Half-life- 2-8 days.
  • Acts as a surface immunoglobulin on the B cells.
  • Serves as recognition receptors for antigens.

IgE:

  • Half-life- 1-5 days
  • Causes type I hypersensitivity.
  • It is the only heat labile antibody.
  • Levels are raised in helminthic infections.

IgA:

  • Half-life- 6 days
  • It is of 2 types- Serum IgA and Secretory IgA 
  • Secretory IgA (A dimer) results in mucosal immunity.

questions.text: The following egg belongs to which of the following parasite?
questions.solution:
The image shows a non-operculated, yellowish-brown egg with a lateral spine near the rounded posterior end is suggestive of Schistosoma mansoni.

Adult worms of S. mansoni live in the inferior mesenteric vein and their infective form is fork-tailed cercaria.

Following skin penetration by cercariae, a pruritic rash termed cercarial dermatitis or swimmers itch develops locally which is self-limiting.

After 4- 8 weeks of the cercarial invasion, high worm load, and egg antigen stimuli lead to the formation of immune complexes which result in serum sickness-like illness termed Katayama fever. They present with high-grade fever, rash, arthralgia, hepatosplenomegaly. lymphadenopathy and eosinophilia. 

When eggs get deposited in the small intestine, patients develop abdominal pain and blood dysentery for a long time called intestinal bilharziasis. The eggs deposited in the intestinal wall lead to microabscesses, granulomas, hyperplasia, and fibrosis. 

The drug of choice is praziquantel 40mg/kg single oral dose. Oxamniquine 15mg/kg single oral dose is also an effective dose. It distorts the tegument of the male worm and makes the worm more susceptible to the lethal action of the immune system.

In Schistosoma hematobium, the egg has a terminal spine.

In Schistosoma japonicum, the egg has no spine but shows a lateral small rudimentary knob.

The life cycle of schistosomes is represented below:

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman is admitted to the ICU with fever and hypotension. She has rigours, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhoea. Her BP is 70/50 mmHg, with a pulse of 140 bpm, and a temperature of 39.5°C. She is minimally responsive. Skin examination reveals generalized erythroderma but no signs of skin infection. Examination per vagina reveals a retained tampon that is immediately removed. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above presentation of fever, hypotension, erythroderma, vomiting, and the finding of a retained vaginal tampon, point towards a likely diagnosis of staphylococcal toxic shock syndrome.

Toxic shock syndrome (TSS) is a toxin-mediated disease that is most commonly associated with staphylococcal and group A streptococcal infections. Staphylococcal TSS on the other hand is associated with the toxic shock syndrome toxin-1 (TSST-1), which binds directly to the MHC II complex and T-cell receptors. This results in a massive increase in cytokines interleukin-2 (IL-2), interferon γ, and tumour necrosis factor (TNF), leading to a cytokine storm. 

Staphylococcal TSS is associated with the use of a highly absorbent tampon. Nonmenstrual cases are seen in patients with surgical or postpartum wound infections, with nasal and wound packing.

Clinical featires include include fever >102 °F, diffuse macular erythroderma with desquamation after 1-2 weeks, hypotension, and the involvement of multiple organ systems(liver, kidneys, gastrointestinal tract, and/or CNS). 

The T-cell activation which produces the cytokine storm in TSS can be seen in the image below:

Other options:

Option A: Rocky Mountain spotted fever is caused by Rickettsia rickettsii. In this condition, the rash begins on wrists and ankles and spread centripetally. The appearance of rash on palms and soles happens later in the disease. Lesion evolves from blanchable macules to petechiae. Headache, myalgias, and abdominal pain can accompany the infection.

Option B: Invasive meningococcal disease presents with meningitis, sepsis (ie, meningococcemia), or a combination of both. Meningitis is the most common complication of meningococcal bacteremia. It usually begins suddenly with an intense headache, vomiting, photophobia, confusion, and a stiff neck. The condition may progress to a coma within a few hours.

Option D: Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome is a disorder commonly seen in newborns and children. It presents with multiple fluid-filled blisters that rupture easily on applying mild pressure.

questions.text: The following image depicts:
questions.solution:
The image depicts the production of monoclonal antibodies by hybridoma technology.

The following are the steps involved in hybridoma technology:

  • Mice are immunized with an antigen. After several weeks of immunization, blood samples are obtained from mice for measurement of serum antibodies.
  • When the antibody titer is high enough, mice are commonly boosted by injecting antigen without adjuvant intraperitoneally or intravenously. Then the mice are euthanized and their spleens removed for in vitro hybridoma cell production.
  • Fusing antibody-producing spleen cells, which have a limited life span with myeloma cells (derived from an immortal tumor of lymphocytes) results in a hybridoma that is capable of unlimited growth.
  • The cells are cultured in a medium containing hypoxanthine, aminopterin, and thymidine (HAT medium) which allows only the fused cells to survive in culture.
  • Monoclonal antibodies are then harvested.
